verses.text: He has set his foundation on the holy mountain;

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 87 The object of this psalm is to glorify Jerusalem, or Zion, the seat of God’s special presence; see Ps. 46; 48; 76. The unique contribution of Ps. 87 is to give a glimpse of the universal character of God’s worship. Its universalistic language brings to mind the future day when the Gentiles should be “fellow heirs” in the gospel (Eph. 3:6).

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:1
rsbNotes.text:
87:1 holy mount. God is omnipresent: He is everywhere. Nevertheless, God met His people in an intimate and special way at Zion. See notes Ps. 2:6; 29:6; 46:2.

he founded. This refers to the building of the temple on Mount Zion, north of the city of David and towering over it.

verses.text: the LORD loves the gates of Zion more than all the dwellings of Jacob.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:2
rsbNotes.text: 87:2 loves . . . more than. The point is not that God hated other parts of Israel, but that He blessed Jerusalem with His presence. After the temple was built, there was only one designated place for the official worship of God—at Jerusalem (Deut. 12).

verses.text: Glorious things are said of you, O city of God: Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:3
rsbNotes.text: 87:3 of you are spoken. Referring to the divine pronouncement to follow in the next few verses.

verses.text: "I will record Rahab and Babylon among those who acknowledge me- Philistia too, and Tyre, along with Cush - and will say, 'This one was born in Zion.'"

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:4
rsbNotes.text:
87:4 those who know me. There were occasional foreigners, like Rahab and Naaman, who worshiped the Lord during the Old Testament period (cf. Ex. 12:38). This amazing verse looks forward to whole foreign nations bowing down to God.

mention. This formal introduction to the divine pronouncement uses the idea of the “book of the living” (Ps. 69:28; cf. Ex. 32:32; Ps. 139:16; Is. 4:3; Rev. 21:24–27).

Rahab and Babylon. Rahab is a name for Egypt (Is. 30:7). Egypt and Babylon were the two superpowers who continually fought against Israel.

Philistia. Israel’s traditional enemy on the Mediterranean coast west of Judah.

Tyre. An affluent sea power north of Israel.

Cush. Biblical Cush is the remote region south of Egypt, including parts of modern Eritrea, Ethiopia, and Sudan.

verses.text: Indeed, of Zion it will be said, "This one and that one were born in her, and the Most High himself will establish her."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:5
rsbNotes.text: 87:5 were born in her. The verse refers metaphorically to a spiritual birth in Zion. Zion is mother to the spiritual birth of peoples from all over the world.

verses.text: The LORD will write in the register of the peoples: "This one was born in Zion." Selah

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:6
rsbNotes.text: 87:6 registers the peoples. See v. 4, note on “mention” (“book of the living.”)

verses.text: As they make music they will sing, "All my fountains are in you."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 87:7
rsbNotes.text: 87:7 my springs. Physical thirst stands for spiritual thirst (Ps. 42:1, 2), that can only be satisfied in Jerusalem, God’s chosen place.
